section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 2. describe the major functions of the family;
content: The functions of the family in contemporary Caribbean society: (a) as a unit of procreation; (b) as a social unit for rearing children, namely, the socialisation of the individual; (c) as an economic unit for satisfying basic needs; (d) as a social unit for satisfying emotional and psychological needs.
specific_objectives: describe the major functions of the family
content_items: The functions of the family in contemporary Caribbean society: (a) as a unit of procreation
(b) as a social unit for rearing children, namely, the socialisation of the individual
(c) as an economic unit for satisfying basic needs
(d) as a social unit for satisfying emotional

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 3. compare different family types and unions in the Caribbean;
content: Differences in family types and unions in the Caribbean: Types – nuclear, extended, sibling households, single parent family; Unions – visiting relationships, consensual or common law, monogamy, legal marriage.
content_items: unions in the Caribbean: Types – nuclear, extended, sibling households, single parent family
Unions – visiting relationships, consensual or common law, monogamy, legal marriage.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 4. examine the roles, relationships and responsibilities of adult and sibling members of a Caribbean family;
content: Roles, relationships and responsibilities of adult and sibling members of the Caribbean family.
specific_objectives: sibling members of a Caribbean family
content_items: sibling members of the Caribbean family.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 5. explain the causes and effects of the changes in the roles of family members in Caribbean society;
content: Factors which contribute to the changing roles and responsibilities of men and women in the Caribbean family: (a) status of women in society; (b) choice of employment; (c) available technology; (d) leisure activities; (e) educational opportunities.
specific_objectives: effects of the changes in the roles of family members in Caribbean society
content_items: Factors which contribute to the changing roles
women in the Caribbean family: (a) status of women in society

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: Results of the changing roles and responsibilities of men and women in the Caribbean family: (a) identity crisis; (b) marginalisation of the male; (c) role conflict; (d) development of self-esteem and confidence of women/ independence of women.
content: Identity/development/change – the modern Caribbean woman; male identity crisis.
specific_objectives: women in the Caribbean family: (a) identity crisis
confidence of women/ independence of women.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 6. describe factors which assist in the preparation for parenthood;
content: Preparation for parenthood – physical, economic, emotional and psychological readiness.
specific_objectives: describe factors which assist in the preparation for parenthood
content_items: Preparation for parenthood – physical, economic, emotional

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 7. examine the characteristics of effective parenting;
content: Characteristics of a good parent: Problem solving skills, communication skills, socialising skills, disciplinary skills, knowledge of good nutrition, showing of love/warmth, money management skills.
specific_objectives: examine the characteristics of effective parenting
content_items: Characteristics of a good parent: Problem solving skills, communication skills, socialising skills, disciplinary skills, knowledge of good nutrition, showing of love/warmth, money management skills.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 8. formulate strategies for dealing with contemporary social issues that influence Caribbean family life;
content: Contemporary social issues which influence Caribbean family life – teenage pregnancy, street children, alternative life styles, substance abuse, juvenile delinquency, sexually transmitted diseases, child abuse, poverty, desertion, suicide, incest, domestic violence, trafficking in persons, care and concern of the aged and those with special needs.
specific_objectives: formulate strategies for dealing with contemporary social issues that influence Caribbean family life
content_items: Contemporary social issues which influence Caribbean family life – teenage pregnancy, street children, alternative life styles, substance abuse, juvenile delinquency, sexually transmitted diseases, child abuse, poverty, desertion, suicide, incest, domestic violence, trafficking in persons, care

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 10. account for the cultural diversity of the Caribbean region;
content: The cultural diversity of the Caribbean region. (a) Existence of cultural patterns, customs, ceremonies, religions and festivals in the Caribbean region; (b) Promotion of ancestral customs, art, craft, language, music, dance and folklore by national organisations and groups.
specific_objectives: account for the cultural diversity of the Caribbean region
content_items: The cultural diversity of the Caribbean region. (a) Existence of cultural patterns, customs, ceremonies, religions
(b) Promotion of ancestral customs, art, craft, language, music, dance

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 12. outline the characteristics of primary, secondary, formal and informal groups;
content: Characteristics of social groups: (a) structure; (b) common goals; (c) voluntary or involuntary membership; (d) marks of identity; (e) common needs, interest and values; (f) specific ways of interacting determined by rules and regulations; (g) established patterns of behaviour; (h) cooperation to achieve group goals; (i) sanctions.
specific_objectives: outline the characteristics of primary, secondary, formal
content_items: (f) specific ways of interacting determined by rules

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 13. describe the requirements for cohesion in groups and institutions;
content: Requirements for group cohesion – leadership, control, cooperation, authority, commitment and loyalty.
specific_objectives: describe the requirements for cohesion in groups
content_items: Requirements for group cohesion – leadership, control, cooperation, authority, commitment

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 14. explain the different types of interaction within and among social groups;
content: Aspects of social interaction within and among groups: competition, conflict, cooperation, compromise.
specific_objectives: explain the different types of interaction within
content_items: among groups: competition, conflict, cooperation, compromise.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 15. describe the characteristics of institutions;
content: Characteristics of institutions. Institutions as: (a) A social norm: (i) made up of norms, mores and values; (ii) endures over time; (iii) can be modified; (iv) influences the working of society; (v) forms the basis for the development of organisations. (b) An organisation: (i) hierarchical structure; (ii) specific function; (iii) written rules; (iv) fixed sanctions; (v) endure over time; (vi) symbols; (vii) rituals.
content_items: Characteristics of institutions. Institutions as: (a) A social norm: (i) made up of norms, mores
(v) forms the basis for the development of organisations. (b) An organisation: (i) hierarchical structure

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 16. evaluate the functions of institutions in society;
content: Functions of institutions. (a) Economic; (b) Educational; (c) Recreational; (d) Religious; (e) Political.
specific_objectives: evaluate the functions of institutions in society

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 17. describe the electoral processes and systems used to elect a government in the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: (a) Definition of the following terms and concepts: government, political party, constituency, candidate, electorate, voters’ list, floating voter, representative, adult suffrage, franchise, manifesto, ballot, hung parliament, government of national unity, coalition government.
specific_objectives: systems used to elect a government in the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: concepts: government, political party, constituency, candidate, electorate, voters’ list, floating voter, representative, adult suffrage, franchise, manifesto, ballot, hung parliament, government of national unity, coalition government.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: (b) Electoral processes (c) Electoral systems: First – past – the – post and Proportional Representation (PR). Advantages and disadvantages.
content: Cooperation/interaction – between parties in a coalition government; a government of national unity; political parties and the electoral body. Development/change – the demands for electoral reform. Integration – monitoring of elections by CARICOM observers.
specific_objectives: (b) Electoral processes (c) Electoral systems: First – past – the – post
content_items: Cooperation/interaction – between parties in a coalition government
the electoral body. Development/change – the demands for electoral reform. Integration – monitoring of elections by CARICOM observers.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 18. describe how political parties prepare for elections;
content: Preparation for elections: (a) select candidates; (b) raise funds; (c) conduct campaigns; (d) identify important issues; (e) monitor the party in power/opposition; (f) monitor the electoral processes; (g) commission public opinion polls; (h) publish manifesto.
specific_objectives: describe how political parties prepare for elections

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 19. outline the factors that influence the outcomes of elections;
content: Impact of the following on elections: (a) media coverage; (b) campaign advertising; (c) public opinion polls; (d) voter turnout; (e) voter attitude to government; (f) campaign strategy; (g) campaign spending.
specific_objectives: outline the factors that influence the outcomes of elections
content_items: Impact of the following on elections: (a) media coverage

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 20. describe the factors that influence voter participation in elections;
content: Influences on voter turnout: (a) Campaign issues; (b) Candidates; (c) Voter attitudes towards government; (d) Voter loyalty to political parties; (e) Voter apathy; (f) Education; (g) Age; (h) Income.
specific_objectives: describe the factors that influence voter participation in elections
content_items: Influences on voter turnout: (a) Campaign issues

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 21. differentiate among the types of government systems in the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: Types of government systems – Crown Colony, Constitutional Monarchy, Republic.
specific_objectives: differentiate among the types of government systems in the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: Types of government systems – Crown Colony, Constitutional Monarchy, Republic.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 22. describe the structure of government;
content: Structure of government – Principle of separation of powers. (a) Legislature – structure, composition and functions, steps in making laws, the role of the Opposition, the role of the Head of State. (b) Executive – composition and function, the role of the Civil Service. (c) Judiciary – Structure of the court system, functions of Magistrates’ Courts, High Courts, Privy Council, Caribbean Court of Justice (d) Role of the security systems, for example, police service, prison service.
content_items: Structure of government – Principle of separation of powers. (a) Legislature – structure, composition
functions, steps in making laws, the role of the Opposition, the role of the Head of State. (b) Executive – composition

function, the role of the Civil Service. (c) Judiciary – Structure of the court system, functions of Magistrates’ Courts, High Courts, Privy Council, Caribbean Court of Justice (d) Role of the security systems, for example, police service, prison service.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 23. evaluate the functions of government;
content: Functions of government: (a) Raise revenue through direct and indirect taxation. (b) Provide social services: welfare, education, health, public utilities. (c) Manage the finances of the country (budgeting). (d) Maintain law and order. (e) Create employment opportunities. (f) Maintain international relations. (g) Defend the nation state.
content_items: Functions of government: (a) Raise revenue through direct
indirect taxation. (b) Provide social services: welfare, education, health, public utilities. (c) Manage the finances of the country (budgeting). (d) Maintain law
order. (e) Create employment opportunities. (f) Maintain international relations. (g) Defend the nation state.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 24. describe the relationship between citizens and governments as stated in the constitution;
content: Relationship between citizen and government as stated in the constitution. (a) Definition of the following terms and concepts: constitution, democracy, authoritarian. (b) Human rights, freedoms and responsibilities. (c) Role of the Ombudsman.
specific_objectives: governments as stated in the constitution
content_items: government as stated in the constitution. (a) Definition of the following terms
concepts: constitution, democracy, authoritarian. (b) Human rights, freedoms

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 25. identify the essentials of good governance;
content: Characteristics of good governance – participation, independence of the judiciary, transparency, accountability, responsiveness to the needs of citizens, access to information, prudent use of resources, efficient civil service, and consultation, tolerance of freedom of expression.
specific_objectives: identify the essentials of good governance
content_items: Characteristics of good governance – participation, independence of the judiciary, transparency, accountability, responsiveness to the needs of citizens, access to information, prudent use of resources, efficient civil service,
consultation, tolerance of freedom of expression.

section:
unit for: satisfying emotional and
psychological needs
objective: 26. interpret statistical data in the form of tables, graphs and charts on elections.
content: Statistical data relating to elections.
specific_objectives: interpret statistical data in the form of tables, graphs

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 1. explain and use correctly concepts and terms associated with human and physical resources.
content: Explanation of terms and concepts: (a) Concepts related to human resources: Population, birth rate, death rate, natural increase, life expectancy, infant mortality rate, fertility rate, migration, immigration, emigration, net migration, brain drain, urbanisation, depopulation, population density, population distribution dependency ratio, employment, unemployment, underemployment, unemployable, labour force, sustainable development, population census, resource, human resource, (b) Concepts related to physical resources: development, environment, conservation, energy, renewable resource, natural resource, non- renewable resource, infrastructure, food security, pollution, conservation, global warming, greenhouse effect. Environmental impact and assessment.
content_items: concepts: (a) Concepts related to human resources: Population, birth rate, death rate, natural increase, life expectancy, infant mortality rate, fertility rate, migration, immigration, emigration, net migration, brain drain, urbanisation, depopulation, population density, population distribution dependency ratio, employment, unemployment, underemployment, unemployable, labour force, sustainable development, population census, resource, human resource, (b) Concepts related to physical resources: development, environment, conservation, energy, renewable resource, natural resource, non- renewable resource, infrastructure, food security, pollution, conservation, global warming, greenhouse effect. Environmental impact

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 2. describe the structure and characteristics of a population;
content: Major characteristics of a population according to age, sex, occupation, ethnicity, religion, dependency ratio.
content_items: Major characteristics of a population according to age, sex, occupation, ethnicity, religion, dependency ratio.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 3. explain the factors influencing population distribution;
content: Factors influencing population distribution: the relief of the land, climate, fertile areas, location of mineral resources, developed areas, types of vegetation.
specific_objectives: explain the factors influencing population distribution
content_items: Factors influencing population distribution: the relief of the land, climate, fertile areas, location of mineral resources, developed areas, types of vegetation.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4. outline factors influencing population change;
content: Factors influencing population change: birth rate, death rate, migration.
content_items: Factors influencing population change: birth rate, death rate, migration.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 5. outline the sources and uses of population statistics;
content: Sources of population statistics: (a) National census, Registrar’s Office, Office of Naturalisation, records of religious institutions. (b) uses of population statistics: For planning related to: housing, health care, education, employment, social welfare, infrastructural development.
content_items: Sources of population statistics: (a) National census, Registrar’s Office, Office of Naturalisation, records of religious institutions. (b) uses of population statistics: For planning related to: housing, health care, education, employment, social welfare, infrastructural development.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 6. explain the causes and consequences of migration;
content: Migration: (a) Causes: Push and pull factors that influence rural- urban, urban- rural migration among Caribbean countries and migration between the Caribbean and other parts of the world; (b) Consequences of migration to the individual, the host country and to the country of origin.
content_items: pull factors that influence rural- urban, urban- rural migration among Caribbean countries
(b) Consequences of migration to the individual, the host country

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 7. explain the need for developing human resources;
content: The need for: Productive workers, creative and critical thinking and problem solving skills.
specific_objectives: explain the need for developing human resources
content_items: The need for: Productive workers, creative

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 8. explain the factors that contribute to the development of human resources;
content: Development of human resources through: (a) nutrition and health; (b) the availability of and access to primary and curative health care; (c) education (basic, moral, vocational and professional training, rehabilitation, retraining); (d) the availability and access to various types of educational institutions; (e) the provision of scholarships; (f) sports; (g) culture.
specific_objectives: explain the factors that contribute to the development of human resources
content_items: Development of human resources through: (a) nutrition
access to various types of educational institutions

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 9. explain the factors that influence employment, unemployment and underemployment;
content: Factors that influence employment, unemployment and under- employment: (a) availability and use of capital; (b) level and range of skills demanded versus those available; (c) availability and creation of markets, trading patterns and preferences; (d) level of technology available in relation to resource development.
specific_objectives: explain the factors that influence employment, unemployment
content_items: range of skills demanded versus those available
(d) level of technology available in relation to resource development.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 10. describe the factors and procedures to be considered in choosing a job or being self - employed;
content: Preparation for the world of work: (a) choosing a job or self-employment – making choices, considering values, needs, interests, ambitions. (b) procedural requirements for job selection and self- employment: (i) collecting information on jobs; (ii) listing available options; (iii) assessing available options; (iv) determining consequences of choice; (v) obtaining resources; (vi) rights and responsibilities of workers.
specific_objectives: procedures to be considered in choosing a job or being self - employed
content_items: Preparation for the world of work: (a) choosing a job or self-employment – making choices, considering values, needs, interests, ambitions. (b) procedural requirements for job selection
self- employment: (i) collecting information on jobs

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 11. identify the location and uses of the major natural resources in the Caribbean region;
content: (a) Location of major natural resources: (i) Renewable – agricultural land, water, forests, beaches, marine life, solar energy, wind. (ii) Non-renewable – petroleum, bauxite, gold, diamond, other minerals, geothermal energy. (iii) Uses of natural resources
specific_objectives: uses of the major natural resources in the Caribbean region
content_items: (a) Location of major natural resources: (i) Renewable – agricultural land, water, forests, beaches, marine life, solar energy, wind. (ii) Non-renewable – petroleum, bauxite, gold, diamond, other minerals, geothermal energy. (iii) Uses of natural resources

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 12. describe proper and improper practices related to the sustainable development and use of natural resources and their effects on the environment and the population;
content: (a) Proper practices, for example, conservation. (b) Effects of proper practices, for example, food security. (c) Improper practices, for example, over- cropping. (d) Effects of improper practices, for example, pollution, global warming, food shortages.
specific_objectives: improper practices related to the sustainable development
content_items: (a) Proper practices, for example, conservation. (b) Effects of proper practices, for example, food security. (c) Improper practices, for example, over- cropping. (d) Effects of improper practices, for example, pollution, global warming, food shortages.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 13. represent and interpret data related to human and physical resources.
content: Data related to human and physical resources: population, migration, employment and unemployment statistics.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 1. explain and use correctly concepts and terms associated with regional integration;
content: Explanation of the following terms and concepts related to regional integration: bilateral agreement, multilateral agreement, common market, single market, single economy, economic integration, independent state, underdeveloped country, developing country, developed country, trade liberalisation, globalisation, multinational corporation, regionalism, trading bloc, fiscal policy, monetary policy.
content_items: concepts related to regional integration: bilateral agreement, multilateral agreement, common market, single market, single economy, economic integration, independent state, underdeveloped country, developing country, developed country, trade liberalisation, globalisation, multinational corporation, regionalism, trading bloc, fiscal policy, monetary policy.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 2. describe the major challenges facing the Caribbean Region; (m)
content: Major challenges: (a) small size, small national markets; (b) lack of diversification; (c) unemployment and underemployment; (d) low levels of production and productivity; (e) differences in resource distribution; (f) high levels of indebtedness (debt burden); (g) high level and cost of imports; (h) shortage of skilled workers; (i) inadequate technology; (j) low value of exports; (k) difficulties in accessing markets of developed countries; (l) shortage of capital; vulnerability to natural disasters.
specific_objectives: describe the major challenges facing the Caribbean Region
content_items: Major challenges: (a) small size, small national markets
(k) difficulties in accessing markets of developed countries

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 3. outline the major stages in the integration movement;
content: (a) Stages (i) West Indies Federation. (ii) Caribbean Free Trade Association (CARIFTA). (iii) Caribbean Community (CARICOM). (iv) Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) (v) Association of Caribbean States (ACS) (vi) The CARICOM Single Market and Economy (CSME). (b) Membership (i) West Indies Federation. (ii) CARIFTA. (iii) CARICOM. (iv) OECS (v) ACS (vi) CSME.
specific_objectives: outline the major stages in the integration movement
content_items: (a) Stages (i) West Indies Federation. (ii) Caribbean Free Trade Association (CARIFTA). (iii) Caribbean Community (CARICOM). (iv) Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS) (v) Association of Caribbean States (ACS) (vi) The CARICOM Single Market
Economy (CSME). (b) Membership (i) West Indies Federation. (ii) CARIFTA. (iii) CARICOM. (iv) OECS (v) ACS (vi) CSME.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 4. state the functions of: a. OECS Secretariat b. CARICOM Secretariat c. Conference of Heads of Government
content: (a) Functions of OECS and CARICOM secretariats; (b) Functions of Conference of Heads of Government.
specific_objectives: state the functions of: a. OECS Secretariat b. CARICOM Secretariat c. Conference of Heads of Government
content_items: (b) Functions of Conference of Heads of Government.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 5. outline the objectives of the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), CARICOM, The CARICOM Single Market and Economy (CSME);
content: Objectives of: (a) OECS and CARICOM (i) functional cooperation; (ii) integration of the economies of member states; (iii) harmonisation of foreign policy. (b) The CARICOM Single Market (i) free movement of goods and services; right of establishment;
specific_objectives: outline the objectives of the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS), CARICOM, The CARICOM Single Market
content_items: (ii) integration of the economies of member states
(iii) harmonisation of foreign policy. (b) The CARICOM Single Market (i) free movement of goods

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: (ii) free movement of capital; (iii) free movement of skilled labour. (c) The CARICOM Single Economy Harmonisation of: (i) Fiscal (tax) policies; (ii) Monetary policies (including a single CARICOM currency); (iii) External trade policy (iv) Legislation (custom, companies); (v) Sectoral policies in agriculture, manufacturing, fisheries. (d) The Regional Development Fund.
content: Conflict – resulting from violation of terms of integration agreements. Development/change – the creation of a single economic space in the region. Justice – role of Caribbean Court of Justice (CCJ) in interpreting protocols and settling disputes among member states. Provision of assistance for disadvantaged members of CSME.
specific_objectives: (iii) free movement of skilled labour. (c) The CARICOM Single Economy Harmonisation of: (i) Fiscal (tax) policies
(ii) Monetary policies (including a single CARICOM currency)
(v) Sectoral policies in agriculture, manufacturing, fisheries. (d) The Regional Development Fund.
content_items: Conflict – resulting from violation of terms of integration agreements. Development/change – the creation of a single economic space in the region. Justice – role of Caribbean Court of Justice (CCJ) in interpreting protocols
settling disputes among member states. Provision of assistance for disadvantaged members of CSME.

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 6. outline the factors that promote regional integration;
content: Factors promoting regional integration: (a) common cultural heritage; (b) common economic and social issues; (c) effects of globalisation, trade liberalisation and trading blocs; (d) vulnerability to economic shocks and natural disasters.
specific_objectives: outline the factors that promote regional integration
content_items: Factors promoting regional integration: (a) common cultural heritage

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 7. describe the factors that hinder regional integration;
content: Factors that hinder regional integration: (a) geography of region; (b) absence of common model or strategy for development; (c) differences in stages of growth and development; (d) competition for location of industries; (e) conflict between territorial and regional demands and loyalties (insularity); (f) absence of common currency; (g) unequal distribution of resources; (h) lack of diversification in production; (i) influence of multinational corporations.
specific_objectives: describe the factors that hinder regional integration
content_items: Factors that hinder regional integration: (a) geography of region
(b) absence of common model or strategy for development

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 8. analyse the benefits of regional integration;
content: Benefits of regional integration: (a) reduction in unemployment and underemployment; (b) better response to economic implications of globalisation and trade liberalisation; (c) improvement in the quality of life; (d) reduction in the inequality of wealth distribution; (e) free movement of goods, labour and capital; (f) increased market size; (g) improved levels of international competitiveness; (h) expansion of trade; (i) increased co-operation among member states.
specific_objectives: analyse the benefits of regional integration
content_items: Benefits of regional integration: (a) reduction in unemployment
(b) better response to economic implications of globalisation
(c) improvement in the quality of life
(d) reduction in the inequality of wealth distribution

section: SECTION B: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF RESOURCES
objective: 10. explain the role of regional agencies in the integration process.
content: Areas of regional cooperation: (a) The Caribbean Agricultural Research and Development Institute (CARDI) (Agriculture); (b) West Indies Cricket Board (WICB), Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association of Football (CONCACAF); (c) OECS sports desk (sports); (d) Caribbean Environmental and Health Institute (CEHI), Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) (health); (e) Caribbean Disaster Emergency
specific_objectives: explain the role of regional agencies in the integration process.
content_items: Areas of regional cooperation: (a) The Caribbean Agricultural Research
(b) West Indies Cricket Board (WICB), Confederation of North, Central American

objective: 1. define and use correctly major terms and concepts associated with communication;
content: Communication, communiqué, news agency, medium, message, receiver, sender, transmission, journalism, propaganda, censorship, freedom of expression, freedom of the press, oral traditions, voice-mail, electronic mail, website, teleconferencing, telecommuting, telecommunications, pager, encoding, libel, slander, Internet, copyright, plagiarism.
content_items: Communication, communiqué, news agency, medium, message, receiver, sender, transmission, journalism, propaganda, censorship, freedom of expression, freedom of the press, oral traditions, voice-mail, electronic mail, website, teleconferencing, telecommuting, telecommunications, pager, encoding, libel, slander, Internet, copyright, plagiarism.

objective: 2. describe the various forms of communication used in the Caribbean;
content: Forms of communication used in the Caribbean. (a) Non-verbal: pictograms, screams, signals, signs, gestures, postures, mime, art forms. (b) Verbal: speech, print, song and drama.
specific_objectives: describe the various forms of communication used in the Caribbean
content_items: Forms of communication used in the Caribbean. (a) Non-verbal: pictograms, screams, signals, signs, gestures, postures, mime, art forms. (b) Verbal: speech, print, song

objective: 3. explain how forms and media of communication are influenced by geographical, socio-cultural and technological factors; (iii)
content: (a) Media of communication: messengers, mail, telegraph, telex, telephones, courier, radio, television, print, satellite, facsimile, computers, video cassette recorders, cell phones, portable music players. (b) Factors that influence forms and media of communication: (i) geographical – distance, climate, rivers, mountains, sea; (ii) socio-cultural – languages, socio- economic status, beliefs, custom, religions; technological – changes in technology: energy, electronics, transistor, design of instrument, type of instrument, computer.
specific_objectives: media of communication are influenced by geographical, socio-cultural
content_items: (a) Media of communication: messengers, mail, telegraph, telex, telephones, courier, radio, television, print, satellite, facsimile, computers, video cassette recorders, cell phones, portable music players. (b) Factors that influence forms
media of communication: (i) geographical – distance, climate, rivers, mountains, sea
(ii) socio-cultural – languages, socio- economic status, beliefs, custom, religions
technological – changes in technology: energy, electronics, transistor, design of instrument, type of instrument, computer.

objective: Media of communication
content: Factors

objective: 4. describe the factors responsible for breakdown in communication;
content: Breakdown in communication due to: age and gender difference, prejudices, beliefs, ideology, status, unresolved conflict, mistrust, stress, strained relationships, failure of equipment.
specific_objectives: describe the factors responsible for breakdown in communication
content_items: Breakdown in communication due to: age
gender difference, prejudices, beliefs, ideology, status, unresolved conflict, mistrust, stress, strained relationships, failure of equipment.

objective: 5. describe how the regional mass media can help promote regional integration;
content: Regional mass media and regional integration. Role of: radio and television stations, printing establishments, regional news agencies and departments of information.
specific_objectives: describe how the regional mass media can help promote regional integration
content_items: television stations, printing establishments, regional news agencies

objective: 6. examine the challenges presented by the global media in relation to cultural penetration and the development of the region;
content: Effects of global mass media on Caribbean society with regard to: identity, attitudes, behaviour, perceptions, freedom of expression, creativity, nationalism and regionalism.
specific_objectives: examine the challenges presented by the global media in relation to cultural penetration
content_items: Effects of global mass media on Caribbean society with regard to: identity, attitudes, behaviour, perceptions, freedom of expression, creativity, nationalism

objective: 7. analyse the effects of different forms of ownership and control of mass media in the Caribbean communication networks;
content: (a) Forms of ownership: (i) Private – individuals, groups, companies, corporations; (ii) Public – Government corporations; (iii) Joint – partnership between public and private enterprise. (b) Effects of forms of ownership.
specific_objectives: analyse the effects of different forms of ownership
control of mass media in the Caribbean communication networks
content_items: (a) Forms of ownership: (i) Private – individuals, groups, companies, corporations
private enterprise. (b) Effects of forms of ownership.

objective: 8. evaluate the ways in which cultural heritage in the Caribbean is transmitted and transformed;
content: Transfer of cultural heritage through communication by: (a) cultural groups; (b) artists; (c) mass media; (d) institutions;
specific_objectives: evaluate the ways in which cultural heritage in the Caribbean is transmitted
content_items: Transfer of cultural heritage through communication by: (a) cultural groups

objective: 9. outline the regulatory functions of government and media associations in relation to the media;
content: Regulatory practices: licensing, mediating in disputes, censorship boards, code of ethics.
specific_objectives: outline the regulatory functions of government
media associations in relation to the media
content_items: Regulatory practices: licensing, mediating in disputes, censorship boards, code of ethics.

objective: 10. describe the ways in which artistic and creative work are protected;
content: Protection of creative or artistic work: copyright laws, institutions for the preservation and protection of creative or artistic work.
specific_objectives: describe the ways in which artistic
content_items: Protection of creative or artistic work: copyright laws, institutions for the preservation
protection of creative or artistic work.

objective: 11. describe how communications technology can help promote regional integration.
content: Communications technology and regional integration. Role of: cellular phones, Internet, electronic transfers, electronic mail, telecommunications networks.
specific_objectives: describe how communications technology can help promote regional integration.
content_items: regional integration. Role of: cellular phones, Internet, electronic transfers, electronic mail, telecommunications networks.

objective: 1. define and use correctly the major terms and concepts associated with consumer affairs;
content: Terms and Concepts (a) consumer, budgeting, saving, consumption, goods, services, demand, supply, income, disposable income, investment, bonds, ownership, pricing, marketing, thrift, credit union, black market, hire purchase, dumping, electronic transaction, e- commerce, securities, dividend, exchange rate, devaluation, inflation.
content_items: Concepts (a) consumer, budgeting, saving, consumption, goods, services, demand, supply, income, disposable income, investment, bonds, ownership, pricing, marketing, thrift, credit union, black market, hire purchase, dumping, electronic transaction, e- commerce, securities, dividend, exchange rate, devaluation, inflation.

objective: 2. differentiate among the categories of consumers;
content: Categories of consumers: (a) as individuals, groups and institutions; (b) consumer of goods; (c) consumer of services; (d) consumer of credit: personal loans credit cards hire purchase mortgages
specific_objectives: differentiate among the categories of consumers
content_items: Categories of consumers: (a) as individuals, groups
(d) consumer of credit: personal loans credit cards hire purchase mortgages

objective: 3. assess the factors which influence consumer demand for goods and services;
content: Factors that influence demand: (a) size of income; (b) taste patterns; (c) savings; (d) credit facilities and conditions; (e) fluctuations in supply; (f) quality; (g) pricing; (h) access to information; (i) advertising; (j) consumer expectations.
specific_objectives: assess the factors which influence consumer demand for goods
content_items: Factors that influence demand: (a) size of income

objective: 4. explain how consumers use modern technology to conduct transactions;
content: Use of modern technology in transactions: (a) tele-banking; (b) ATM; (c) E-commerce; (d) Internet banking; (e) debit and credit cards. Benefits of the use of modern technology: (a) security issues: reduced need to carry cash; (b) convenience: easy access to goods and services, money and financial records; (c) time-saving; (d) accessible 24 hours.
specific_objectives: explain how consumers use modern technology to conduct transactions
content_items: Use of modern technology in transactions: (a) tele-banking
credit cards. Benefits of the use of modern technology: (a) security issues: reduced need to carry cash

objective: 5. evaluate the role of government and other agencies in protecting and educating consumers; (c)
content: Forms of consumer protection: (a) Government: (i) price control; (ii) quality control (Bureau of Standards); (iii) fair trading practices (Fair Trading Commission); (iv) regulations governing imports, export and use of consumer goods; (v) consumer affairs division; (vi) supervision of credit facilities; (vii) food and drug inspection (Food and Drugs Division). (b) Consumer Groups and Organisations Pressure Groups
content_items: Forms of consumer protection: (a) Government: (i) price control

objective: 6. describe the ways the consumer can protect himself/herself;
content: (a) The consumer being informed about: (i) types of exploitation in relation to goods and services; (ii) use of modern technology; (iii) consumer rights and responsibilities; (iv) factors influencing consumer decisions and the extent of individual control.
specific_objectives: describe the ways the consumer can protect himself/herself
content_items: (a) The consumer being informed about: (i) types of exploitation in relation to goods

objective: 7. describe the ways consumers practise thrift in the Caribbean;
content: (a) Ways of practising thrift: (i) shopping wisely for goods and services; (ii) use and care of possessions; (iii) conservation and recycling; (iv) budgeting. (b) Benefits of thrift to: (i) self; (ii) society.
specific_objectives: describe the ways consumers practise thrift in the Caribbean
content_items: (a) Ways of practising thrift: (i) shopping wisely for goods
(iv) budgeting. (b) Benefits of thrift to: (i) self

objective: 8. explain reasons for and benefits of saving;
content: Saving: (a) Forms of saving; (b) reasons for saving; (c) benefits of saving to: (i) the individual; (ii) the country; (iii) the region.
content_items: (c) benefits of saving to: (i) the individual

objective: 9. outline the benefits of credit unions to consumers in the region;
content: Benefits of credit unions to members: (a) saving regularly; (b) lower interest on loans; (c) dividend on shares; (d) financial counselling; (e) easier access to loans; (f) patronage refund; (g) self-discipline and self-reliance; (h) sense of ownership.
specific_objectives: outline the benefits of credit unions to consumers in the region
content_items: Benefits of credit unions to members: (a) saving regularly

objective: 10. develop strategies to deal with the effects of devaluation and inflation on consumers;
content: (a) Effects of devaluation and inflation: (i) higher prices of goods and services; (ii) higher prices and reduced purchasing power; (iii) lower standard of living; (iv) retrenchment. (b) Strategies to deal with effects: for example, (i) home gardening; (ii) self-employment.
specific_objectives: develop strategies to deal with the effects of devaluation
content_items: (iv) retrenchment. (b) Strategies to deal with effects: for example, (i) home gardening

objective: 11. evaluate the effects of globalisation and trade liberalisation on consumers;
content: Effects of globalisation and trade liberalisation: (a) cheaper goods and services; (b) wider choice of goods and services; (c) more widespread use of technology for transactions; (d) competition from developed countries for available markets.
content_items: (c) more widespread use of technology for transactions
(d) competition from developed countries for available markets.

objective: 12. explain how consumers can contribute to the sustainable development of the region.
content: Consumers and sustainable development of the region: (a) awareness of integration objectives; (b) preference for local and regional goods and services; (c) investment in local and regional businesses; (d) conservation of the region’s resources; prudent use of foreign exchange; (e) creative ways of utilising regional agricultural products; (f) consumption of products that contribute to a healthy lifestyle; (g) saving to provide capital for investment.
specific_objectives: explain how consumers can contribute to the sustainable development of the region.
content_items: sustainable development of the region: (a) awareness of integration objectives
(e) creative ways of utilising regional agricultural products
(f) consumption of products that contribute to a healthy lifestyle
(g) saving to provide capital for investment.

objective: 2. differentiate between the types of tourism products available in the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: Types of tourism products: – sand, sea, sun, nature or eco, health, sports, cultural or heritage, music festivals, special events.
specific_objectives: differentiate between the types of tourism products available in the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: Types of tourism products: – sand, sea, sun, nature or eco, health, sports, cultural or heritage, music festivals, special events.

objective: 3. explain the factors that influence the development of tourism in the host and supply countries;
content: Factors that influence the development of tourism in the: (a) host country: (i) accessibility; (ii) availability, cost and quality of tourist services; (iii) perception of safety and security; (iv) political stability; (v) infrastructure, especially sanitation and water supply, roads, air and seaports. (b) supply country: (i) disposable income; (ii) effectiveness of promotion; (iii) marketing; (iv) accessibility; (v) cost and availability of transportation.
specific_objectives: explain the factors that influence the development of tourism in the host
content_items: Factors that influence the development of tourism in the: (a) host country: (i) accessibility

objective: 4. analyse the contribution of land based and cruise tourism to the economy of the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: Tourism and the Commonwealth Caribbean economy: (a) foreign exchange earnings, income and expenditure; (b) direct employment, such as hotel workers; (c) indirect employment through linkages with other sectors of the economy (agriculture, craft, transportation and other ancillary services); (d) government revenue (taxes on hotels, departure tax, restaurant licenses, head tax);
specific_objectives: analyse the contribution of land based
cruise tourism to the economy of the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: the Commonwealth Caribbean economy: (a) foreign exchange earnings, income
(b) direct employment, such as hotel workers
(c) indirect employment through linkages with other sectors of the economy (agriculture, craft, transportation
(d) government revenue (taxes on hotels, departure tax, restaurant licenses, head tax)

objective: (e) relationships between expenditure on infrastructure in resort areas and elsewhere in the country; (f) effect of tourism development on availability of land and labour for agriculture.
content: Cooperation/interaction – between the tourism industry and the other sectors of the economy. Integration – regional approach for dealing with the challenges of the cruise industry.
specific_objectives: (e) relationships between expenditure on infrastructure in resort areas
(f) effect of tourism development on availability of land
content_items: the other sectors of the economy. Integration – regional approach for dealing with the challenges of the cruise industry.

objective: 5. outline employment and career opportunities in the tourism industry;
content: Careers and Opportunities in tourism: (a) types of occupation: managerial, clerical, administrative, professional, technical, unskilled; (b) conditions of employment: trade union membership, job security, opportunities for promotion, fringe benefits; (c) qualifications needed; (d) opportunities for training and entrepreneurship.
specific_objectives: career opportunities in the tourism industry
content_items: Opportunities in tourism: (a) types of occupation: managerial, clerical, administrative, professional, technical, unskilled
(b) conditions of employment: trade union membership, job security, opportunities for promotion, fringe benefits

objective: 6. assess the impact of the tourism industry on the physical environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: Tourism and the physical environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean: (a) resort development and its effects on the aesthetic value of the local environment; (b) changes in ecology, reefs and tidal patterns caused by land reclamation, sewage disposal and pollution of water bodies – ocean, sea, rivers; (c) tourism and conservation of flora, fauna, historical sites, role of the Caribbean Conservation Association, local National Trusts, and national parks.
specific_objectives: assess the impact of the tourism industry on the physical environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: the physical environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean: (a) resort development
its effects on the aesthetic value of the local environment
tidal patterns caused by land reclamation, sewage disposal
pollution of water bodies – ocean, sea, rivers
conservation of flora, fauna, historical sites, role of the Caribbean Conservation Association, local National Trusts,

objective: 7. assess the impact of tourism on the socio-cultural environment in the Commonwealth Caribbean;
content: Tourism and the socio-cultural environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean: (a) effects on land ownership, land use, natural beauty and use of beaches; (b) visitors’ perception of Caribbean societies; (c) opportunities for visitors to meet Caribbean people; (d) relationships between citizens and visitors, citizens and returning nationals: (i) two-way cultural exchange between citizen and visitor; (ii) influence of lifestyles, language, dress and values;
specific_objectives: assess the impact of tourism on the socio-cultural environment in the Commonwealth Caribbean
content_items: the socio-cultural environment of the Commonwealth Caribbean: (a) effects on land ownership, land use, natural beauty
(c) opportunities for visitors to meet Caribbean people
returning nationals: (i) two-way cultural exchange between citizen

objective: 8. evaluate government policies that influence the development of tourism;
content: Government policies that influence the development of tourism: (a) meeting infrastructure requirements; (b) providing a well-trained workforce; (c) addressing environmental concerns; (d) addressing social problems, such as crime; (e) creating a favourable investment climate; (f) providing an overseas marketing and promotional presence in key markets (Tourist Boards, Departments, Bureaus, Ministries of Tourism).
specific_objectives: evaluate government policies that influence the development of tourism
content_items: Government policies that influence the development of tourism: (a) meeting infrastructure requirements
(d) addressing social problems, such as crime
promotional presence in key markets (Tourist Boards, Departments, Bureaus, Ministries of Tourism).

objective: 9. assess the contribution of local, regional and international agencies to the development of tourism;
content: Supportive services for tourism. (a) Role and function of: (i) Hotel Associations, Tourist Boards, Departments, Bureaus and Ministries of Tourism; (ii) Caribbean Tourism Organisation; (iii) Caribbean Hotel Association; (iv) Hospitality Training Institutions. (b) role of donor agencies – Caribbean Development Bank, European Union, Organization of American States and Canadian Inter- development Agencies.
specific_objectives: assess the contribution of local, regional
international agencies to the development of tourism
content_items: function of: (i) Hotel Associations, Tourist Boards, Departments, Bureaus
(iv) Hospitality Training Institutions. (b) role of donor agencies – Caribbean Development Bank, European Union, Organization of American States

objective: 10. outline the challenges facing the tourism industry in the region;
content: Challenges facing the tourism industry in the region: (a) security of funding for investment; (b) marketing; (c) research; (d) training; (e) shortage of labour; (f) water supply; (g) global terrorism; (h) lack of direct air access for major tourist- generating markets. (i) emerging destinations; (j) cruise ship policies.
specific_objectives: outline the challenges facing the tourism industry in the region
content_items: Challenges facing the tourism industry in the region: (a) security of funding for investment
(h) lack of direct air access for major tourist- generating markets. (i) emerging destinations

objective: 11. describe ways in which tourism can be used to promote regional integration;
content: Promoting regional cooperation and integration through tourism by: (a) marketing the Caribbean as a single destination; (b) recognition of the tourism products packaged by each Caribbean country; (c) common economic and marketing policies; (d) create linkages within Caribbean – (communication); (e) concept of aviation hubs.
specific_objectives: describe ways in which tourism can be used to promote regional integration
content_items: integration through tourism by: (a) marketing the Caribbean as a single destination
(b) recognition of the tourism products packaged by each Caribbean country

objective: 12. describe how communications technology impacts on the tourism industry in the Caribbean.
content: Impact of communications technology on the tourism industry: (a) E- ticketing; (b) Internet booking (reservations); (c) information gathering; (d) advertising; (e) feedback.
specific_objectives: describe how communications technology impacts on the tourism industry in the Caribbean.
content_items: Impact of communications technology on the tourism industry: (a) E- ticketing
